d:dictionary.d:entry: cerebral metabolic rate of oxygen (CMRO2) CBF is linearly related to cerebral oxidative metabolism

ul.li: The signal from static tissue fluctuates due to physiological and thermal noise effects. This interacts with the signal derived from ASL, thereby increasing the physiological noise in the image. Therefore, after the labeling duration (Fig. 2), additional RF pulses are applied to reduce the tissue signal. [Efficiency of inversion pulses for background suppressed arterial spin labeling]
background suppression allows ASL MRI data to be reliably obtained at 3T in less than one minute (36)
Read-out technique
three-dimensional (3D) fast imaging sequences, such as GRASE (a hybrid of gradient and spin echo)

A hybrid approach that simulates CASL using many short pulses termed “pseudocontinuous” or “pulsed continuous” ASL (pCASL) combines these schemes to provide better sensitivity and ease of implementation for body coil transmitters (23,24) (Applications of Arterial Spin Labeled MRI in the Brain).
[Recommended implementation of arterial spin-labeled perfusion MRI for clinical applications: a consensus of the ISMRM perfusion study group and the European consortium for ASL in dementia]
series of short RF and gradient pulses
One drawback in pCASL is its sensitivity to resonance offset at the labeling plane, which can cause it to shift
the most important acquisition parameters to choose are the labeling duration and the post-labeling delay

CASL, or continous ASL, where the inversion of the arterial blood occurs continuously through the application of a continuous RF pulse. During the acquisition of the control image, an RF pulse is supplied above the image slice to account for magnetic distortions caused by the pulse itself, but the pulse itself will not label any blood. This method of inversion is also called flow-driven inversion.

In continuous ASL (CASL) arterial blood water is continuously and selectively labeled as it passes through a labeling plane (Williams DS, Detre JA, Leigh JS, Koretsky AP. Magnetic resonance imaging of perfusion using spin inversion of arterial water. Proc Natl Acad Sci USA. 1992; 89(1):212–216. [PubMed: 1729691]).

PASL, or pulsed ASL, where the inversion of the arterial blood occurs over a specific area. The RF pulse is applied in a spatially selective manner (slice-specific). Several versions exist, including EPISTAR (echo planar imaging and signal targeting with alternating radiofrequency) and FAIR (flow-sensitive alternating inversion recovery). Please refer to the image on the right. These methods of inversion are also referred to as spatial inversion.

In pulsed ASL (PASL) a short RF pulse is used to instantaneously invert blood and tissue, and can be applied either below the brain (20,21), or to the entire brain with subsequent selective inversion of the imaging slices to produce a magnetization difference between blood and brain water (22) (Applications of Arterial Spin Labeled MRI in the Brain).

d:entry.d:title: default mode network
d:entry.h2: Where are the differences between default network vs resting state?

ul.li: k-space is the 2D or 3D Fourier transform of the MR image measured
these complex values (a+i*b) are sampled using a pulse sequence, i.e. an accurately timed sequence of radiofrequency and gradient pulses
k-space holds raw data before reconstruction
k space is a graphic matrix of digitized MR imaging data that represents the image prior to Fourier transform analysis
one line in k-space equals one phase encoding step

d:entry.d:title: Echo planar imaging

ul.li: Read-out technique
the sign of the readout (frequency-encoding) gradient is rapidly alternated and gradient echoes are acquired
after the 180° RF pulse, the frequency-encoding gradient oscillates rapidly from a positive to a negative amplitude, forming a train of gradient echoes

d:entry.div:
Advantages:
reduced imaging time
decreased motion artefact
ability to image rapid physiologic processes of the human body Disadvantages:
Sensitive to susceptibility effects
Sensitive to main magnetic field inhomogeneity
Long gradient echo train causes greater T2* weighting
Requires high-performance gradients

d:dictionary.d:entry: Velocity-Selective ASL VSASL or VASL was introduced to provide great transit delay immunity and spatial specificity (Wong et al., 2006)

d:entry.d:title: The Label
d:entry.p: The area that has been magnetically labelled in ASL imaging.

d:entry.d:title: MNI Space
d:entry.h1: Montreal Neuro Institute map of the brain

d:entry.d:title: Aterial Spin Labeling

ul.li: magnetically labeled arterial blood water
ASL depends on vascular water exchange with tissue
more heavily weighted toward the microvasculature than conventional BOLD
ASL can be used to provide quantitative CBF information, whereas BOLD is for the most part a relative measure

Another main issue/challenge for perfusion-based rs-fMRI is the relatively low temporal resolution. Due to the pairwise subtraction of label and control acquisitions, as well as the requirement for a postlabeling delay, each perfusion image generally takes 6–8 sec to acquire, in contrast to the 1–3 sec required by conventional BOLD rs-fMRI.

First, arterial blood labeling is achieved by a combination of RF pulses and gradients in order to invert the longitudinal magnetisation (T1) of blood water protons. In other words, the water molecules within the arterial blood are labeled magnetically.

The labeling plane must be located in a region where the relevant feeding arteries are relatively straight and perpendicular (90˚) to the labeling plane. Prior to positioning, an MR angiogram (picture) may be acquired such that the feeding vessels are visualised.

After a period of time (called the transit time), this 'paramagnetic tracer’ flows into slice of interest where it exchanges with tissue water. The inflowing inverted spins within the blood water alter total tissue magnetization, reducing it and, consequently, the MR signal and image intensity. During this time, an image is taken (called the tag image).

The experiment is then repeated without labeling the arterial blood to create another image (called the control image). The control image and the tag image are subtracted to produce a perfusion image. This image will reflect the amount of arterial blood delivered to each voxel within the slice within the transit time.
ASL signal that results from activation is cleaner than what is normally observed in utilizing your average BOLD

tissue perfusion in classical units of ml/g/min requires a nominally diffusible tracer. This was first accomplished in MRI using deuterated water (1,2) and fluorinated (3,4) tracers, and in the future hyperpolarized tracers may be used, but currently the most effective approach uses magnetically labeled arterial blood water, termed “arterial spin labeling” (ASL)
ASL has been shown to have high reproducibility over periods of day, weeks, or months (109– 111)

ol.li: The ratio of tissue water versus intravascular water in the brain is in the order of 20:1, meaning that only a very small proportion of the measured water signal is affected by the magnetic label.

When the labeled water enters the tissue, over 90–95 % exchanges with the tissue water instantaneously. For this reason, it is impossible to measure any labeled venous blood flowing out of the tissue, due to the very short T1 relaxation time compared with the equilibrium time.

One of the major confounds when using ASL comes from magnetisation transfer effects. The application of off- resonance RF pulses to label the arterial blood proximal to the tissue of interest will induce a reduction of MR signal that mimics the signal decrease induced by the labeled blood water exchange. This is due to the fact that protons in macromolecules have a very short T2 and thus a very broad frequency spectrum. As such, the off-resonance RF pulses used in any asymmetrical ASL sequence will inadvertently not only saturate the arterial blood but also protons in these macromole- cules. This saturation will then be transferred to tissue water molecules reducing the MR signal [Quantitative interpretation of magnetization transfer].

d:entry.h2: Why are ASL time series potentially less sensitive to motion and low-frequency drift effects (Liu et al., 2002), as well as low-frequency physiological noise?
Why is ASL noise a lot whiter than BOLD noise. (Wang 2003)?
How is water linked to glucose metabolism and neuronal activity?
How does ASL measure the capacity for absolute quantification of CBF?

ul.li: Once the magnet is sited in the imaging suite, its field will be further distorted by the presence of metal in pipes, wires, ducts, and structural beams in the immediate environment. Fringe fields of nearby scanners may also affect the field of the newly installed magnet.
Shimming is the process by which the main magnetic field (Bo) is made more homogenous

Shimming may be passive, active, or both. In passive shimming small pieces of sheet metal or ferromagnetic pellets are affixed at various locations within the scanner bore. In active shimming, currents are directed through specialized coils to further improve homogeneity.

d:dictionary.d:entry: Susceptibility Susceptibility is a measure of the extent to which a substance becomes magnetized when it is placed in an external magnetic field. A synonym for susceptibility is "magnetizability".
RARE rapid acquisition relaxation enhanced read-out technique
Moyamoya disease Long transit delays of blood in brain
Velocity Labeling means of eliminating arterial transit time dependence
Hyperperfusion Too much perfusion unexpected hyperperfusion suggesting stroke mimics such as complicated migraine (40) and focal seizure

Interictal Hypometabolism ASL MRI has been shown to correlate with interictal hypometabolism by FDG-PET in temporal lobe epilepsy in a few preliminary studies (65–67), some showing correlations with PET data, and ictal hyperperfusion has also been visualized (41,68)
Calibrated BOLD relative changes in ASL CBF and BOLD contrast with vasoactive stimuli are used to draw inferences about oxygen metabolism changes with functional stimulation

Pediatric ASL Several physiological properties of the pediatric brain are beneficial for ASL (70)
Blood flow rates are generally higher in children compared to adults (except in newborns) (71)
water content of the brain is also higher in children than adults, which yields a greater concentration and half-life of the tracer (blood water)
offers quantitative cerebral blood flow (CBF), no task activation needed
In healthy children older than 4 to 5 years, a trend of decreasing CBF in the whole brain, gray and white matter with age has been observed (73,74)
relative rCBF increases with age (after adjusting global CBF) were observed in the frontal cortex, cingulate cortex, angular gyrus, and hippocampus (74), which may reflect the later maturation of cortical regions associated with executive function, cognitive control, integrative and memory function (76)
Distal situated away from the centre of the body or from the point of attachment

Positron Emission Tomography Inject a radiotracer (dye)
Advantage over fMRI
Disadvantages

d:entry.d:title: Echo planar imaging and signal targeting with alternating radiofrequency
d:entry.h1: Echo planar imaging and signal targeting with alternating radiofrequency

ul.li: Removal of extrameningeal tissue from the MRI volume of the whole head
Find boundary between brain and the skull
Use darkness of CSF and skull on T1 scans for edge detection
Strong edges are not always that strong due to:
Finite resolution
Annatomical connections with body

d:entry.d:title: Front/Back Matter
d:entry.div: This is a front matter page of the sample dictionary.

To see this page,
Open "Go" menu.
Choose "Front/Back Matter" menu item. If it has sub-menu items, choose one of them.

To prepare the menu item, do the followings.
Prepare this page source as an entry.
Add "DCSDictionaryFrontMatterReferenceID" key and its value to the plist of the dictionary. The value should be the string of this page entry id.
